subject: Confusion (RE: [junit] Testing & Design (was: testing private  methods))
msgSnippet: ... don t ... Separate threads! Much different. I thought you meant go to another group and talk about this... No-one could argue against separate threads --
messageBody:
On 2002-04-02 at 23:28 Manuel Amago wrote:

>> I'm not sure how you can separate the two discussions. Could
>> you tell me how Unit Testing can be discussed without discussing
>> its impact on design?
>
>I am sorry that I made myself misunderstood in this way. What I
>intended to say was: lets make the discussion clear for those who
don't
>want to participate in/read the 'testing private methods' thread, and
>move to a 'Testing & Design' thread that brings the issue into better
>focus. I see that my mistake was to omit 'private method' when I
>mentioned separating Design and (private method) Unit testing.

Separate threads! Much different. I thought you meant "go to another
group and talk about this..." No-one could argue against separate
threads -- it's just nicer to know that a message's contents match its
subject.

>What we could be saying then is:
>- to those who want to test private methods, use another tool
>- to those who want to learn about how testing can improve design,
keep
>on reading (this thread)
>
>The statements above are not mutually exclusive, and, therefore, can
be
>done in conjunction.

No argument can be made against such precise statements. Much clearer.

>Also, we could try to discover how many of this mailing list's readers
>would actually like to be able to test private methods (democracy?).
If
>we find this to be a respectable percentage, we could then proceed to
>find out whether they know of the benefits testing only public methods
>has on design.

I admit that the general flow of discussion is:

A: I want to test private methods.
B: No, you don't. You want to change your design.
A: No, I don't. I want to test private methods.
B: But your design...
A: Don't bore me with design! I have work to do!

It's easy to see how each side drifts further apart from the point.
It's the reason I've stayed out of the discussion more and more lately,
until my recent idea about how to word my position in a better way.
That idea was simply triggered by the most recent "I want to test
private methods."

>> [...] JUnit was not built for that purpose. Not only that, its
>> creators feel
>> (well Kent, anyway; I don't know how Erich feels) that one of
>> the strengths
>> of JUnit is that when the tests become painful to write,
>> there is a tendency
>> for the design to have an organic weakness that prevents the
>> testing. As
>> Kent says in this case, it's an opportunity to learn about
>> your design.
>
>I also know about Kent's position, and how much testing plays a part
in
>how HE sees development practices should be undertaken (XP, TDD).

Well, it's not just Kent. Sometimes people on this list say, "I'm not
Kent" to dismiss Kent's ideas. It ain't just Kent. Many, many, many of
us agree with Kent, share his experience and hold the common vision.

>> If you are going to say, "Take your testing/design
>> discussions elsewhere,"
>
>I am *really* sorry if my post could be misconstrued in that manner!
>Once again, I believe I mentioned the fact that many an insight has
been
>gained from these discussions. Keep it up!

I apologize for jumping to such a conclusion. Rather a shame that
that's the majority of exercise I get these days...

>> It's all in how you define "unit". To me, it's the exported
>> methods of a
>> class or interface. Kent and Erich may define it differently.
>> Clearly, you
>> define it differently.
>
>I was only voicing my opinion for the testing of private methods being
>as it is a popular request. I myself believe in the benefits of
testing
>public methods only, and therefore have no need for that
functionality.

Then we agree. Nothing could be better. :)

>I would add that, since testing of private methods is such a popular
>request, JUnit's position on the matter should be clearly stated in
the
>documentation (README, index.html, FAQ, ...), and why (pointer to
>Testing & Design discussions). [A quick search on Google revealed
that
>the only place private methods are mentioned on the junit.org site is
>where JUnitX is mentioned.]

I would argue that JUnit is conspicuously silent on the matter, and
what one doesn't say can say much. :) (OK, it's a stretch...)

>> You folks can test private methods until your brain pops out,
>> but just don't
>> expect JUnit to do it out of the box. It was never designed
>> for that. It was
>> never designed for that *on purpose*. I don't know why that
>> is such a big
>> deal.
>
>And it isn't!

So let's get back to normal programming. (Pun intended.)

>I am just questioning whether *on purpose* is actually
>the reason, or whether it was never envisaged to be used that way.

Kent could settle this question, if he reads this. I'm interested to
know.


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
